0.text: This Isn't a School Project. This isn't a homework assignment. This is a product. Something that works, that's deployed, that you can demo to a recruiter and say: I built this. Here's how. Here's why.

1.text: Deployed. Your project lives on the internet, not just localhost. Anyone with the URL can use it. That means real hosting, real domains, real infrastructure decisions.

2.text: Tested. Unit tests and integration tests that run automatically in CI. When you push code, GitHub Actions runs your test suite. No manual testing, no hoping it works.

3.text: Documented. A real README that explains setup. Architecture docs that show how pieces connect. API documentation so others can use your endpoints. Professional communication.

4.text: Interview-Ready. When a recruiter asks 'Tell me about a project you've built,' this is your answer. Architecture diagrams, deployed URL, GitHub link, test coverage. Everything a senior engineer would have.

0.text: Three Paths to Choose. You have three options for your capstone. Each teaches the same production skills but lets you focus on what interests you most. Choose based on what you want in your portfolio.

1.text: Option A: Developer Tool. Build a CLI or web tool that solves a real developer problem. A dependency analyzer, code snippet manager, git helper, or API mock generator. Tools developers actually need.

2.text: Option B: SaaS Product. Build a web application with authentication, data storage, and real features. A habit tracker, bookmark manager, study group coordinator. Something people would actually use.

3.text: Option C: API Platform. Build a production-ready API that other developers could use. A mock data generator, file conversion service, webhook forwarder. Backend-focused with clean documentation.

4.text: Full-Stack Architecture. All paths lead to the same architecture: Frontend or CLI, FastAPI backend, auth service, PostgreSQL database, Redis cache, and CI/CD with GitHub Actions deploying to Railway or Vercel.

0.text: The Four Pillars. Your capstone must meet requirements in four areas: Code Quality, Data Layer, API Layer, and Deployment. Let's break down what production-ready looks like for each.

1.text: Code Quality. Clean, documented code that someone else could contribute to. Comprehensive tests with 80 percent plus coverage. Type hints throughout. Formatting with Black and isort.

2.text: Data Layer. A real database with proper migrations, not just a JSON file. Repository pattern for data access. Caching where appropriate. Your data layer should be swappable.

3.text: API Layer. RESTful API design following best practices. OpenAPI and Swagger documentation that's auto-generated. Authentication, even if simple. Proper error handling with meaningful messages.

4.text: Deployment. CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions that runs tests on every push. Deployed to production on Railway, Vercel, or similar. Environment-based config for dev, staging, and prod. Health checks and monitoring.

5.text: Production Ready. Hit all four pillars and you have a production-ready application. Not a toy projecta real system that demonstrates senior-level engineering practices.

0.text: The Quality Gap. There's a massive gap between 'works on my machine' and 'production quality.' Let's see what separates a school project from a portfolio piece that impresses senior engineers.

1.text: Works vs Deployed. School projects work on your laptop. Production code is deployed with CI/CD and Docker. Your GitHub repo should have a live URL, not just instructions to run locally.

2.text: Print vs Structured Logging. School projects use print debug. Production uses structured logging with levelsinfo, warning, error. Logs are searchable, timestamped, and include context.

3.text: Pass vs Handle Errors. School projects ignore errors with 'if error pass.' Production code has proper error handling with user-friendly messages, error tracking, and graceful degradation.

4.text: No Tests vs 80% Coverage. School projects have no tests. Production code has 80 percent plus coverage that runs in CI. Tests aren't optionalthey're how you prove your code works.

5.text: Senior Engineer Standard. This is what separates junior from senior. When you ship code that meets these standards, you're not just completing an assignmentyou're demonstrating professional engineering practices.
